title: Did the Avestan language sound like Sanskrit? - Quora

response.answer_text: A short example of the recitation in Avestan language (Jasa me awenghe Mazda)  Avestan: “Jasa me awanghe Mazda! Jasa me awanghe Mazda! Jasa me awanghe Mazda! Mazdayasnō ahmi, Mazdayasnō Zarathushtrish fravarāne astūtaschā fravaretaschā. Āstuye humatem manō, āstuye hūkhtem vachō, astuye hvarshtem shyaothnem. Āstuye daēnām vanghuhīm Māzdayasnīm, fraspāyaokhedhrām, nidhāsnaithishem, khavaētvadathām ashaonīm, yā hāitināmchā, būshyeintināmchā mazishtācha, vahishtāchā, sraēshtāchā, yā āhūirish Zarathushtrish. Ahurāi Mazdāi vīspā vohu chinahmi. Aeshā asti daēnayāo Māzdayasnōish āstūistish. Ashem vohū vahishtem astī, ushtā astī, ushtā ahmāi, hyat ashāi vahishtāi ashem.” English: “Do Thou come to my help, O Mazda! Do Thou come to my help, O Mazda! Do Thou come to my help, O Mazda! I am a servant of Mazda, I profess myself to be a Zarathushtrian who pledged himself to the service to Mazda. I pledge my mind to good thoughts, I pledge my speech to good words, I pledge my actions to good deeds. I pledge myself to the service to Mazda which is the preeminent religion, which supports reconciliation and non-violence and dedication to family, the rightful religion which of all religions that exist or shall be, is the greatest, the best and the most beautiful; it is the divine religion revealed by Zarathushtra. I testify that there is no other originator of all good things than Lord Mazda. Such is the creed of the Mazdaist religion. Divine justice is the supreme good, it is a source of hapinnes. Happy the man who behaves justly for the sake of the supreme justice.”

Avestan language and Rigvedic Sanskrit have a lot of similarities. Modern Persian /Farsi /Dari /Tadjik and late Sanskrit then Pali and later still Prakit Indian languages belonging to same proto-Indo-Iranian languages group.
They were certainly not mutually intelligible if that’s what you’re asking. You can get an idea of the distance between them at Sanskrit to Avestan.
